chapter.title: Using the right possessive
chapter.para: The possessive form indicates ownership. Nouns and pronouns have possessive forms.

section.title: Converting nouns into possessive nouns
section.para: These are the different rules for converting nouns into their possessive forms:

varlistentry.term: Add a lone ' to the end of a plural noun that all ready ends in s:

listitem.para: Update all of the students' computers.
Email each of the projects' reports to the project manager.

varlistentry.term: Treat plural nouns that do not end in s the same as a singular noun:

listitem.para: Install Linux on all of the children's computers.
Bring those people's laptops in for repair.

varlistentry.term: If a noun is compound, convert only the final noun to its possessive form:

listitem.para: Install Linux on admin and manager's computers.
Bring the student and teachers' laptops in for repair.

section.title: Converting pronouns into possessive pronouns
section.para: Pronouns have their own special possessive forms, separate from their root words. In technical writing, the gender neutral ones are the most common:
For personal ownership in the third person, use their, whether it refers to a singular or plural noun:

informalexample.para: Give your user a GPG key so that their email can be encrypted.
Give all of your users GPG keys so that their emails can be encrypted.

section.para: For personal ownership in the second person, use your:

informalexample.para: Do not give your password to anyone.

section.para: If a pronoun refers to a nonhuman, use its:

informalexample.para: Post the checksum of an RPM so its integrity is verifiable by users.

section.para: The plural form of its is also their:

informalexample.para: Post the checksums of all your RPM packages so that their integrity is verifiable.

section.title: Using its and it's
section.para: The words its and it's notoriously get confused for one another in writing. You don't think about the words when you speak, because they're pronounced exactly the same way, but when you write them, it matters which one you use.
There are two simple rules you can use to remember which to use:

listitem.para: The word it's, like all contractions, is a combination of two words: it and is. Whenever you see it's in a sentence, replace it with it is. If it does not make sense, then it is not used correctly. For example:

informalexample.para: Open the computer and re-seat it's RAM.
Open the computer and re-seat it is RAM.

listitem.para: In this example, it makes no sense to say "re-seat it is RAM." Obviously, the writer intended to use its.
In technical documentation, contractions are generally avoided. Use its as a possessive pronoun, and use it is instead of it's.

section.title: Using your and you're
section.para: The words your and you're also get confused for one another in writing.
The same rules about its and it's apply to your and you're. To reiterate:

listitem.para: The word you're, like all contractions, is a combination of two words: you and are. Whenever you see you're in a sentence, replace it with you are. If it does not make sense, then it is not used correctly:

informalexample.para: To get the most out of a Linux desktop, replace you're single-button mouse with a three-button mouse.
To get the most out of a Linux desktop, replace you are single-button mouse with a three-button mouse.

listitem.para: In this example, it makes no sense to say "you are single-button mouse." Obviously, the writer intended to use your.
In technical documentation, contractions are generally avoided. Use your as a possessive pronoun, and use you are instead of you're.
